Description: Fungal infections occur when fungi invade skin nails or internal organs causing itching redness and discomfort. Treatment includes topical antifungals like clotrimazole and oral agents such as fluconazole for severe cases.

Allergies are immune system reactions to harmless substances such as pollen or dust that leading to symptoms like sneezing itching or swelling. Antihistamines and corticosteroids are commonly used under doctor supervision.
GERD involves stomach acid reflux damaging the esophagus that causing heartburn and regurgitation. Proton pump inhibitors (e.g. pantoprazole) and lifestyle changes are the mainstays of treatment.
This condition results from impaired bile flow leading to jaundice and itching. Ursodeoxycholic acid is prescribed to improve bile flow along with vitamin supplementation.
Drug reactions range from mild rashes to severe allergic responses to medications. Immediate cessation of the drug and use of antihistamines or corticosteroids is essential.
Peptic ulcers are sores in the stomach or small intestine lining caused by acid and H. pylori infection. Treatment includes antibiotics proton pump inhibitors and acid reducers.
AIDS is caused by HIV severely weakening the immune system and increasing vulnerability to infections. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is critical to control viral replication.
Diabetes mellitus causes high blood sugar due to insulin deficiency or resistance. Treatment involves lifestyle modificationoral hypoglycemics like metformin or insulin injections.
Gastroenteritis is inflammation of the stomach and intestines causing vomiting and diarrhea often due to infections. Oral rehydration salts and supportive care are crucial for recovery.
Asthma is a chronic airway inflammation causing wheezin breathlessness and cough. Inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators like salbutamol are used to manage symptoms.
Hypertension is persistently high arterial pressure increasing cardiovascular risk. Treatment involves lifestyle changes and medications such as amlodipine or ACE inhibitors.

Migraine is a neurological disorder with recurrent headaches and sensitivity to light or sound. Acute treatment includes analgesics and triptans; preventive drugs may be prescribed for frequent attacks.
This degenerative disorder affects neck vertebrae causing pain and stiffness. NSAIDs and physiotherapy form the cornerstone of management.
Bleeding in the brain leads to sudden loss of muscle function on one side. Treatment includes stabilizing blood pressure anticoagulants if appropriate and rehabilitation therapy.
Jaundice is yellow discoloration of skin and eyes due to excess bilirubin often from liver dysfunction. Treatment targets the underlying cause such as hepatitis or bile obstruction.
Malaria is a mosquito-transmitted parasitic infection causing fever chills and anemia. Artemisinin-based combination therapies are the first-line treatment.
Chickenpox is a contagious viral infection with itchy blisters. Antiviral medications like acyclovir reduce severity; supportive care relieves symptoms.
Dengue fever is a viral disease spread by mosquitoes causing high fever and joint pain. Management focuses on hydration and symptom control; platelet transfusions in severe cases.
Typhoid fever is a bacterial illness causing high fever and abdominal symptoms. Antibiotics like azithromycin or ceftriaxone are effective treatments.
Hepatitis A is a viral liver infection transmitted via contaminated food or water. Supportive care with hydration and rest is usually sufficient.
Hepatitis B is a viral infection affecting the liver that may become chronic. Antiviral drugs like tenofovir help control viral replication.
This viral infection causes liver inflammation and may lead to cirrhosis. Direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) such as sofosbuvir offer a cure.
Hepatitis D occurs only in people with hepatitis B and worsens liver disease. Management includes HBV antivirals and interferon therapy.
Hepatitis E is a viral liver infection often spread via contaminated water. Supportive care is usually adequate but severe cases may require hospitalization.
This is liver inflammation due to excessive alcohol intake causing liver damage. Abstinence from alcohol and corticosteroids are part of treatment.
Tuberculosis is a contagious bacterial infection primarily affecting lungs. Standard 6-month treatment includes isoniazid rifampicin ethambutol and pyrazinamide.
A viral infection causing sneezing sore throat and congestion. Treatment is symptomatic with rest fluids and antipyretics.
Lung infection leading to inflamed air sacs filled with fluid. Antibiotics such as amoxicillin and supportive oxygen therapy are indicated.
Swollen veins in the anal canal causing pain and bleeding. Conservative treatment includes topical steroids sitz baths and fiber supplements.
Blockage of blood flow to heart muscle causing tissue damage. Emergency treatment involves aspirin nitroglycerin beta-blockers and urgent reperfusion.
Enlarged twisted veins often in legs due to valve failure. Management includes compression stockings and if needed surgical intervention.
A condition of low thyroid hormone causing fatigue weight gain and cold intolerance. Lifelong levothyroxine replacement is the standard treatment.
Excess thyroid hormone causing weight loss anxiety and palpitations. Antithyroid drugs like methimazole and beta-blockers are used.
Abnormally low blood sugar causing shakiness confusion  or fainting. Immediate glucose intake and adjustment of diabetic medications are essential.
Degenerative joint disease with cartilage loss that leading to pain and stiffness. NSAIDs and physical therapy are primary treatments.
Joint inflammation causing pain and reduced motion; may be autoimmune or degenerative. Disease-modifying drugs and NSAIDs are often prescribed.
Dizziness triggered by head movements due to inner ear calcium crystals displacement. Canalith repositioning maneuvers and vestibular rehab are effective.
Skin condition where pores are clogged with oil and dead cells causing pimples. Topical retinoids and antibiotics are standard treatments.
Infection of urinary system causing pain and frequent urination. Nitrofurantoin and ciprofloxacin are commonly prescribed antibiotics.
Autoimmune skin disorder causing red scaly plaques. Topical steroids and systemic agents like methotrexate are used in severe cases.
Contagious bacterial skin infection causing honey-colored crusted sores. Topical mupirocin or oral antibiotics for widespread cases.
